column1: #text=        Ebstein Anomaly    Larry Chen     Mary Wyers, M.D.
#text=  Children's Memorial Hospital   Abstract   Newborn with cyanosis  Keywords  ebstein anomaly, congenital heart disease, tricuspid valve, cyanosis
column4: Publication Date: 2004-6-15                History    Newborn with cyanosis     Findings    Marked cardiac enlargement with decreased pulmonary vascularity      Diagnosis    Ebstein Anomaly      Differential   cyanosis with decreased pulmonary vascularity: tetralogy of fallot, tricuspid atresia, pulmonary atresia/stenosis, pericardial effusion may lead to enlarged heart but will not lead to cyanosis     Discussion   Ebstein's anomaly is a dysplasia of the tricuspid valve (enlarged, malformed and displaced into the RV).

column1: #text=As a result, contractions become discoordinated leading to tricuspid obstruction and regurgitation.
#text=This leads to a "box shaped heart" with marked cardiac enlargement, especially the RA.

column1: #text=Most patients also have either an ASD or a PFO.
#text=The obstruction leads to decreased pulmonary vascularity.
